title: Baby born with no skin and eyes fused shut can finally cuddle his mother
text:
Baby Ja’bari Gray was born without any skin below his neck – but can now cuddle his mother and siblings 10 months after he was born, thanks to pioneering skin transplant surgery (Pictures: KTRK)

A baby born with no skin below his neck and his eyes fused shut can finally cuddle his mother 10 months after he was born.

Ja’bari Gray has enjoyed affection with his mother Priscilla Maldonado for the first time earlier this month after receiving a pioneering skin transplant.

Ja’bari, who has been cared for at Texas Children’s Hospital in Houston, received skin grown by a lab in Boston, Massachusetts that specializes in helping burns victims.

His grateful mom, who had no idea of Ja’bari’s condition until he was born, told KTRK: ‘That was the first transplant ever that’s been done in his situation and on a baby his age.

‘It was heartwarming, because he was crying when he was laying down, but as soon as I picked him up and had the skin-to-skin contact and put him on my chest, he just stopped crying.

‘Now you can kiss him, touch him, do all that stuff.

‘He got to wear his first set of clothes now, so he’s getting there.’

Ja’bari has astonished doctors with his progress, after they warned his mother the only two other babies born with his condition in the US ended up dying.

His skin has now begun to grow on its own, although his fingers, toes and neck became fused during the three months he spent in intensive care.

The youngster has been taken off pain medication, and his weight has increased from just three pounds when he was born to 18 pounds today.

Ja’bari’s mother Priscilla Maldonado is delighted that she and her older siblings can finally cuddle and comfort her youngest child (Picture: KTRK)

He still faces medical issues, with two surgeries to open his eyelids ending in failure.

Ja’bari, who remains in hospital, also requires further surgery to separate his arms, hands, feet and neck.

But the infant’s mother is grateful for his progress – and says Ja’bari appears to be enjoying life just like any other baby.

She explained: ‘Making coo sounds that normal babies would do, he’s interacting with us.

‘Even though he can’t see us and stuff, he’s still interacting.’
description: Ja'bari Gray underwent a pioneering skin transplant operation at the Texas Children's Hospital in Houston
